title: Resource Relationship
description: A relationship of one rdfs:Resource (http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#Resource) to another, or to a simple named concept. Resources can be thought of as identifiable records or instances of classes and may include, but need not be limited to instances of ltc:ObjectGroup, ltc:OrganisationalUnit, ltc:Taxon, ltc:Event, ltc:GeographicContext, ltc:GeologicalContext, ltc:EcologicalContext, or ltc:ObjectClassification. In the context of Latimer Core, the main purposes of this class are 1. to define different semantic and hierarchical relationships between ObjectGroups, and 2. to support quantified and annotated relationships between ObjectGroups and other LtC classes (such as ltc:Taxon and ltc:GeographicContext) and properties (such as ltc:discipline and ltc:objectType) that describe the contents of the ObjectGroup, using the hasMeasurementOrFact property.

hasIdentifier.description: This property refers to one or more related instances of the Identifier class.

hasReference.description: This property refers to one or more related instances of the Reference class.

relationshipAccordingTo.description: The source (person, organization, publication, reference) establishing the relationship between the two resources.

relatedResourceID.description: An identifier for a related resource (the object, rather than the subject of the relationship).

relatedResourceName.description: A short textual name for the related resource.

relationshipEstablishedDate.description: The date-time on which the relationship between the two resources was established.

relationshipOfResource.description: The relationship of the subject (identified by resourceID) to the object (identified by relatedResourceID).

relationshipRemarks.description: Comments or notes about the relationship between the two resources.

resourceID.description: An identifier for the resource that is the subject of the relationship.

resourceRelationshipID.description: An identifier for an instance of relationship between one resource (the subject) and another (relatedResource, the object).
